newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU seeks urgent information on C.Lyonnais rescue. [CORRECTED 13:50 GMT]
newsitem.headline: EU seeks urgent information on C.Lyonnais rescue. [CORRECTED 13:50 GMT]

text.p: The European Commission is requesting the French government to provide urgent information on the latest rescue plan for troubled bank Credit Lyonnais, a European Union source said on Tuesday.

A letter would be sent to the French representation in Brussels probably later today, the source said. This would contain a "warning" about the need to receive details on a capital injection for the bank in 1997.

Unless this happened shortly, the Commission would be unable to rule on the new measures to assist Credit Lyonnais by the end of March, when the bank's 1996 (corrects from 1995) accounts will be closed, he said.
But he did not comment on a report in the French daily newspaper Liberation that Paris may be ready to provide 12 billion francs ($2.27 billion) in recapitalisation being sought by the bank.
Credit Lyonnais has been assisted by the French state for several years due to a reckeless expansion during the past decade which turned it briefly into Europe's largest bank.

In September, the Commission approved 3.9-billion francs in French emergency aid to avoid liquidity problems which could endanger the bank's viability. But French and Commission officials have acknowledeged that much more is needed if the bank's long-term profitability is to be restored.
